Chapter 11: The Records of the Teachings of the Mountain Tradition, Records of the Teachings of the Mountain Tradition
Zhizhe lectured from a high seat, using eloquent speech.

Now, the Calming and Contemplation is precisely the Dharma path practiced in the mind of Zhizhe.
The causes and effects of one's own practice, and the abilities of transforming others, are all complete.
Jingxi explains it with the Fuxing (Auxiliary Practice). The catalog says:
Our school has three kinds of Calming and Contemplation.
The first is called gradual.
It refers to understanding suddenly but practicing gradually.
This is the Chan PÄramitÄ.
The second is called indeterminate.
It refers to sudden understanding.
The practice may be sudden or gradual.
This is the Six Subtle Gates.
Third, the perfect and sudden.
It refers to both understanding and practice being sudden.
This is the Mohe Zhiguan.
These three types of calming and contemplation differ in their suitability for different capacities.
Although their modes of practice are distinct, they all rely on the perfect truth as their fundamental principle.
